Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech and democratic values.
It creates two classes of citizens, unfairly targeting ordinary citizens.
Judging truth is difficult, and authorities can be wrong, as shown in past public health debates.
The bill includes true information that may be misleading, stifling open discussions.
It favors large digital services and hinders competition from smaller platforms.
Free market competition between platforms can naturally address misinformation.
The extraterritorial application of the bill is problematic and infeasible.
The bill interferes with the implied constitutional freedom of political communication.
Threats and penalties discourage public discourse and resemble authoritarian approaches.
Notable Quotes: The existence of this bill demonstrates a lack of respect for the freedom of speech of Australian citizens.
The task of accurately judging what is true or untrue is virtually impossible.
The bill's threats and penalties imposed on digital platform providers and ordinary users are an affront to freedom of expression and personal liberties.
